hints.content: Start by understanding what a palindrome is. A string is a palindrome if it reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, 'aa', 'aba', and 'racecar' are palindromes.

Consider how the allowed operation (swapping characters between different words) can help in forming palindromes. Think about what characters need to be in the same position for a string to be a palindrome.
Identify the current palindromes in the given list of words. Count how many words are already palindromes before making any swaps. This will help you understand your starting point.
Focus on the structure of the words. A word can become a palindrome if it has an even count of each character, or at most one character can have an odd count (for the middle of the palindrome).
Think about character frequencies. For each word, calculate the frequency of each character. This will help you determine if a word can be rearranged into a palindrome.
Consider how swapping characters can affect the character frequencies of the words. If you can balance the character counts across words through swaps, you can increase the number of palindromes.
Look for pairs of words that can be transformed into palindromes by swapping characters. For example, if one word has excess characters that another word needs, that could be a potential swap.
Remember that you can swap characters within the same word. This means you can also focus on making individual words palindromic before considering swaps between different words.
Consider edge cases, such as when all words are of length 1 or when they contain unique characters. These scenarios might limit the number of palindromes you can create.

Finally, think about the overall strategy: maximize the number of palindromes by first counting the existing ones, then determining how many more can be created through character swaps. Keep track of character counts and potential swaps.

questionNotes: Each word consists only of lowercase English letters.
You can swap characters between any two words, including the same word.
Return the maximum number of palindromes that can be formed after any number of operations.
